chapter.summary: Covers the management of Achilles tendinopathy in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage Achilles tendinopathy in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange admission or a same-day referral to orthopaedics (depending on local protocol) if Achilles tendon rupture is suspected.
  • If Achilles tendon rupture has been excluded:
    • Manage as appropriate any underlying causes, such as:
      • Fluoroquinolone antibiotics — discontinue (discuss with microbiology if unsure regarding alternatives).
      • Hypercholesterolemia — see the CKS topics on Hypercholesterolaemia - familial and Lipid modification - CVD prevention for further information.
      • Diabetes mellitus — see the CKS topics on Diabetes - type 1 and Diabetes - type 2 for further information.
    • Advise the person that:
      • Cold packs or ice can be applied to ease symptoms after acute injury. See the CKS topic on Sprains and strains for more information.
      • Paracetamol can be used for pain relief — nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may be useful for analgesia in the acute phase but are not recommended in the longer term. See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for more information.
      • They should rest — reduce or stop the activity that precipitated the injury. Exercise can be restarted when pain allows.
      • They can weight bear as tolerated.
    • Refer the person to physiotherapy for assessment if their symptoms fail to improve within 7–10 days.
    • Do not inject corticosteroids into or around the tendon.
    • If the person has chronic Achilles tendinopathy or fails to respond to conservative measures, consider referral to a sports physician or orthopaedics for assessment and further treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Secondary care treatments
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Treatments that may be offered in secondary care include:
    • Non-surgical interventions, such as [Uquillas, 2015; Ackermann, 2018b; Martin, 2018; Tu, 2018]: 
      • Eccentric exercise, or a heavy-load, slow-speed (concentric/eccentric) exercise programme (if not already tried).
      • Extracorporeal shock-wave therapy (ESWT) — acoustic shockwaves are passed through the skin to the affected tissue. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) recommends that uncertainty regarding the efficacy of the treatment should be explained to people being offered this treatment [NICE, 2016]. 
    • Surgery
      • Surgery may be indicated in chronic cases and people who have not responded to conservative treatment. Surgery may include debridement and removal of diseased areas of tendon [Uquillas, 2015; Ackermann, 2018b; Maffulli, 2019].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Referral if Achilles tendon rupture is suspected

 

  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the review articles Achilles tendon disorders [Asplund, 2013], Pain at the back of the heel [Morton, 2016], and Acute Achilles tendon rupture [Singh, 2017]. 
Management of underlying causes
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the review article Treatment of Achilles tendinopathy: state of the art, which states that first-line treatment of non-insertional Achilles tendinopathy should include removal of precipitating factors [Ackermann, 2018b]. 
  • The Medicine and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency advises that [MHRA, 2019]:  
    • If tendinitis is suspected, fluoroquinolones must be stopped immediately. 
    • Fluoroquinolone antibiotics are contraindicated where there is a history of tendon disorders related to their use.
Cold packs and ice
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion on conservative management options for non-insertional and insertional tendinopathy in the review article Everything Achilles: knowledge update and current concepts in management: AAOS exhibit selection [Uquillas, 2015] and an evidence summary [BMJ Best Practice, 2019].  
Advice on simple analgesia
  • Recommendations on analgesia in tendinopathy are largely based on expert opinion in review articles: 
    • Paracetamol is recommended as needed for pain [Asplund, 2013]. 
    • Expert opinion in the review article Treatment of Achilles tendinopathy: state of the art [Ackermann, 2018b] and the evidence summary Tendinopathy [BMJ Best Practice, 2019] acknowledges the effectiveness of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for short-term pain relief in musculoskeletal conditions, but notes the lack of evidence to support their long-term use and the potential for adverse effects in the long term.
Rest and weight bearing
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the US clinical guideline Achilles pain, stiffness, and muscle power deficits: midportion Achilles tendinopathy revision 2018 [Martin, 2018] and expert opinion in the review articles Achilles tendon disorders [Asplund, 2013], Everything Achilles: knowledge update and current concepts in management: AAOS exhibit selection [Uquillas, 2015], Heel pain, diagnosis and management [Tu, 2018], Achilles insertional tendinopathy: state of the art [Maffulli, 2019], and Current clinical concepts: conservative management of Achilles tendinopathy [Silbernagel, 2020]. 
Referral to physiotherapy
  • The recommendation to refer to physiotherapy is based on a treatment algorithm described in the review article Achilles tendon disorders [Asplund, 2013] and expert opinion in the review articles Everything Achilles: knowledge update and current concepts in management: AAOS exhibit selection [Uquillas, 2015], Current clinical concepts: conservative management of Achilles tendinopathy [Silbernagel, 2020], and the evidence summary Tendinopathy [BMJ Best Practice, 2019].
    • Stretching and strengthening and eccentric exercises are a component of treatment for tendinopathy and are best guided by an experienced physiotherapist [BMJ Best Practice, 2019].  
  • The US clinical guideline Achilles pain, stiffness, and muscle power deficits: midportion Achilles tendinopathy revision 2018 [Martin, 2018] recommends, on the basis of levels, I, II, and IV evidence, that clinicians should use mechanical loading (either an eccentric or heavy-load, slow-speed [concentric/eccentric] exercise programme) with the aim of decreasing pain and improving function in people with mid-portion Achilles tendinopathy without presumed frailty of the tendon structure. 
Not injecting corticosteroids in or around the tendon
  • A systematic review of randomized controlled trials [Coombes, 2010] looking at efficacy and safety of corticosteroid injections and other injections in the management of tendinopathy, found that corticosteroid injections did not have a beneficial effect in terms of pain reduction in Achilles tendinopathy. Adverse effects including atrophy and tendon rupture were reported.
  • The review article Treatment of Achilles tendinopathy: state of the art states that the role of corticosteroid injections in Achilles tendinopathy is controversial, with an increased risk of complete or partial tendon rupture, and the risk-benefit analysis does not seem to favour their use [Ackermann, 2018b]. Expert opinion in the review articles Everything Achilles: knowledge update and current concepts in management: AAOS exhibit selection [Uquillas, 2015] and Heel pain: diagnosis and management [Tu, 2018] recommends avoidance of corticosteroid injections because of the risk of tendon rupture.
Referral
  • The recommendation to refer to orthopaedics or a sports physician if symptoms are chronic or do not improve with conservative treatment is based on expert opinion in the review articles Achilles tendon disorders [Asplund, 2013] and Everything Achilles: knowledge update and current concepts in management [Uquillas, 2015].
